question: Question_03_(a)
statement:
Consider the function $f(x)=x(x-2)(x+1)$.

Sketch the function.
sols:
We will preface this question by noting that the original intent in the
exam was to understand the sketch well enough to proceed to
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH103/April_2011/Question_3_(b)}{part
(b)}. However, we have decided to present the solution as detailed as
possible for those who would like to improve their curve sketching
techniques.

Now we will complete this question by following a checklist that is
fairly standard for these types of problems.

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Find roots
\item
  Determine any asymptotes
\item
  Determine critical points
\item
  Determine intervals of increase and decrease and local max/min
\item
  Determine intervals of concavity and points of inflection
\item
  Sketch the graph
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{1: Find roots:}

Luckily we have a polynomial that is already written in factored form so
we can read, as the roots, the factors. Therefore if

\[\displaystyle{}f(x)=x(x-2)(x+1)=0\]

then the roots are at $x=0$, $x=2$, $x=-1$.

\textbf{2: Asymptotes:}

Now polynomials are continuous everywhere (their domain is all the real
numbers) and so we do not expect any vertical asymptotes. When looking
for horizontal asymptotes we typically take the limit as $x$ goes to
$\infty$. We don't need to be so formal here because it's clear that as
$x$ gets large then $f(x)$ also gets large as their is nothing (such as
a denominator) to slow its growth. What's to be determined is whether
$f(x)$ gets large and positive or large and negative. If we were to put
a very large positive value of $x$ into $f(x)$ we would get that

\[f(x)=x(x-2)(x+1)\approx{}x^3\]

since adding or subtracting numbers to something large is unaffected.
Now as $x$ goes to $\infty$ then $f(x)$ will go to $\infty$ as well. If
we put in a large negative number, once again adding or subtracting
small numbers will have no affect and once again,

\[f(x)\approx{}x^3\]

which approaches $-\infty$ as $x$ goes to $-\infty$. Therefore,

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x\to\infty}f(x)&=+\infty\\
\lim_{x\to{-\infty}}f(x)&=-\infty.
\end{align*}

\textbf{3. Critical Points:}

In order to find critical points we first need the derivative. In order
to do this we need to apply the product rule three times. Therefore,

\[\displaystyle{}f'(x)=(x-2)(x+1)+x(x+1)+x(x-2)=3x^2-2x-2.\]

Critical points will occur when $f'(x)=0$. Therefore,

\begin{align*}
3x^2-2x-2&=0\\
x=\frac{2\pm\sqrt{4+24}}{6}&=\frac{1}{3}\pm\frac{\sqrt{7}}{{3}}
\end{align*}

are our critical points.

\textbf{4. Intervals of Increase and Decrease and Local Max/Min:}

We have that our derivative is,

\[\displaystyle{}f'(x)=3x^2-2x-2\]

with critical points

\[x=\frac{1}{3}\pm\frac{\sqrt{7}}{{3}}.\]

To find intervals of increasing and decreasing we look at the derivative
between each critical point over the entire domain. If the derivative is
positive then the function is increasing and if the derivative is
negative, the function is decreasing.

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llll@{}}
& $\left(-\infty,\frac{1}{3}-\frac{\sqrt{7}}{{3}}\right)$ &
$\left(\frac{1}{3}-\frac{\sqrt{7}}{{3}},\frac{1}{3}+\frac{\sqrt{7}}{{3}}\right)$
& $\left(\frac{1}{3}+\frac{\sqrt{7}}{{3}},\infty\right)$\\

$\displaystyle {}f'(x)$ & Positive & Negative & Positive\\
$\displaystyle {}f(x)$ & Increasing & Decreasing & Increasing\\
\end{longtable}

From the table we see that the critical point

\[\frac{1}{3}-\frac{\sqrt{7}}{{3}}\]

is a local maximum since the derivative is increasing on the left and
decreasing on the right. By a similar logic we have that the other
critical point

\[\frac{1}{3}+\frac{\sqrt{7}}{{3}}\]

is a local minimum.

\textbf{5. Intervals of Concavity and Points of Inflection:}

In order to determine points of inflection we have to compute the second
derivative. Since the first derivative is just a polynomial we can
easily compute term by term with the power rule to get

\[\displaystyle{}f''(x)=6x-2.\]

Possible points of inflection occur when $f''(x)=0$, i.e. there is a
possible point of inflection as $x=1/3$. In order for it to be a point
of inflection we require that the second derivative change sign as we
cross $x=1/3$. If the second derivative is positive, the graph is
concave up; if it is negative, the graph is concave down.

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}lll@{}}
& $\left(-\infty,\frac{1}{3}\right)$ & $\left(\frac{1}{3},\infty\right)$\\

$\displaystyle {}f''(x)$ & Negative & Positive\\
$\displaystyle {}f(x)$ & Concave Down & Concave Up\\
\end{longtable}

Notice that the change in concavity, confirms that we do indeed have an
inflection point at $x=1/3$.

\textbf{6. Sketch:}

The picture to the right \includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math103Apr20113a.png} shows a
sketch of the graph. We have labelled intervals of increasing with red
and decreasing with blue. Concave up is a thin solid line while concave
down is a thick dashed line. We have placed x's to mark the roots,
filled in circles to mark the local maximum and minimum, and triangles
to indicate the point of inflection.
hints:
What are the roots of $f$? What happens to $f(x)$ when
$x\rightarrow \pm\infty$? In which intervals is $f(x)$ positive, in
which is the function negative? Find any local maxima and local minima.
